awd_titl_txt: Topology and Measure in Dynamics and Operator Algebras
awd_abstract_narration:
Three of the basic ingredients in the structural foundations of modern analysis and its connections with theoretical physics are the concepts of measure, topology, and group. The first of these deals with the notions of volume and size, the second with proximity and convergence, and the third with symmetry and the idea of displacement in space or time. When combined together they form the subject of dynamical systems,  which in its classical origins models the time evolution of physical systems but is nowadays applicable to a wide range of phenomena involving transformations from one state to another. The project will pursue novel relationships between measure and topology that have recently begun to emerge within this dynamical framework and are tightly linked to the related field of operator algebras. The goal is to use this perspective to develop new ways of understanding how  the particular symmetries of a given dynamical system may condition different types of asymptotic behavior, from the deterministic to the chaotic.

While the topological and measure-theoretic perspectives have long between fruitfully intertwined in the theory of operator algebras, in the last several years this symbiosis has been reinvigorated through not only the elaboration of surprisingly far-reaching analogies but also the discovery of new kinds of applications of von Neumann algebra techniques to C*-algebras with structurally profound consequences. The central aim of the project is to reimagine these analogies and techniques in dynamical terms. This will on the one hand forge a novel line of investigation in topological dynamics that intertwines finite approximation properties with asymptotic phenomena like mean dimension, and on the other establish broader connections between group actions and C*-algebras as part of the effort to understand general types of crossed products and their K-theoretic classifiability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first part of the project, carried out by the initial PI, has contributed to the effort to deepen the relationship between ergodic theory, topological dynamics, and C*-algebras through the study of finite approximation, paradoxicality, dimensionality, and asymptotic invariants. One of the main impulses for this work has been the various developments in the classification program for simple separable nuclear C*-algebras over the last decade that have pointed the way to new and extremely fruitful relationships between measure and topology. This has led to advances in the study of topological dynamics and its applications to the structure theory of the associated C*-algebras. One key outcome was a tiling result for free continuous actions of elementary amenable groups on finite-dimensional spaces.

Tiling methods were also employed to develop a theory of sparse connectivity, inspired by work of Austin, for groups and their continuous and measure-preserving actions. Using sparse connectivity conditions it was shown that, for actions of many nonamenable groups, entropy is invariant under certain weak notions of equivalence, in particular Shannon orbit equivalence, in which the cocycle partitions have finite Shannon entropy. As a corollary one obtains rigidity statements for Bernoulli actions of such groups. These results have contributed to the emergence of quantitative orbit equivalence as a field of study and raise many interesting questions connecting rigidity phenomena in dynamics to the geometric structure of groups.

The results of this part of the project were disseminated in a variety of national and international venues, including the Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach in Germany (2019), the Centre International de Rencontres Mathematiques in France (2019 and 2021), the Instituto de Matematicas at UNAM in Mexico City (2019), and the online Expanding Dynamics Summer School (2021).

 The second part of the project carried out by the second PI has contributed to the study of isoperimetry and its applications to asymptotic geometric analysis and, in general, in High Dimensional Phenomena. In particular, the focus was on the volume of Lp centroid bodies, a central notion in the investigation of high dimensional measures in Asymptotic Functional Analysis and Convexity. These objects interpolate between the (dual) zonoids and intersections bodies (when p varies on the interval [-1,1]), connecting the classical Brunn-Minkowski Theory in Convexity with the recently developing Dual Lp theory. The recent work of the PI and his collaborators established a unifying way to investigate isoperimetric inequalities for these classes of bodies. This work has been communicated in Mathematisches Forschungsinstitut Oberwolfach in Germany (2021) and IPAM center in UCLA, by the PI and his collaborators.
